breve.
1. Introduction
Vladimir Nabokov (1899-1977) is one of the greatest American writers. However, his cultural and literary background differs from that of other American writers. He had to abandon his
native language to survive as an artist writing in another language, like Samuel Beckett and Joseph Conrad.
Nabokov’s earlier work was written mainly in Russian in those
cities where he was forced to live after the Russian Revolution,
sharing public acknowledgement of the Russian Nobel prize with
Ivan Bunin. When Nabokov arrived in the States he brought with
AO LXXV (II) Women, exile, past and other puppeteer’s strings... 155
him his Russian language, traditions, and literature. In America,
he kept writing novels and acquiring fame till he, finally, became
a famous recognised novelist after publishing Lolita (1955).
In this study, we are going to analyze the role of women, past
and exile in his short story. There are a few studies focused on
the role and types of women in Nabokov’s novels, such as Rakhimova-Sommers (2001), Delage-Toriel (2007), Idrisova (2007)
and Garipova (2017), but there is not such a study focused on his
short stories.
 We are going to explain how the author started using these
figures in order to deal with the émigré experience in his earlier short production. In this sense, the female figure symbolizes
the spirit of the Russian collectivity, as there is always a “close
association between collective territory, collective identity and
womanhood” (Yuval Davis, 2008: 57). However, the association
of the woman with this spirit of collectivity changes. Therefore,
we will also study examples in which Nabokov uses the female
figures skillfully to create literary puzzles for the reader to solve
in his short stories.
2. Nabokov’s female characters and the longing for the past
As has already been mentioned, when the Russian revolution
took place his new life started in Berlin where the expatriate Russian community had already settled down. They could not go
back to their native land, due to their political ideas. Therefore,
they maintained their memories, culture, language and customs
in their Russian ghettos. It was a way of keeping their national
identity in the environment of destruction and loss in exile (Figes, 2002: 539).
Nabokov’s short stories, especially the first ones, depict expatriate Russian characters. These stories describe Russian expatriates’ loss and loneliness. For example, “The Seaport” (1924)
is based on Nikitin’s loneliness in a French seaport. In “The
Doorbell” (1927), “A Russian Beauty” (1934), and in “A Matter of
Chance” (1924), the characters have to get accustomed to living
156 Asunción Barreras Gómez AO LXXV (II)
by themselves. They are isolated from their fellow Russians and
everything related to their mother Russia. In “The Visit to the
Museum” (1939), for instance, a Russian expatriate’s return to
the USSR is a traumatic, anguishing experience. As in Nabokov’s
case, all the Russian expatriates had lost their friends, relatives,
homes and memories, while fleeing from Russia. Field (1967: 87)
comments that madness and suicide were a normal occurrence
in that atmosphere. The memories of the old Russia cannot exist
within the new USSR. Heldt Monter (1970: 134) remarks that a
metaphor of Nabokov Russian expatriates is a man looking for
his personal truth. It is a search for a mythical past that can only
be recovered by means of memory. Nabokov considered them
keys to achieve the recollections of the past in his literary work.
On the other hand, one can also appreciate how Nabokov associates the female figure to Russia and his Russian past. A characteristic in line with Pwar’s argumentation when he stresses that
the female figure is allegorically used to signify the virtues of
the nation. In fact, many scholars, such as Yuval Davis and Anthias (1989), McClintock (1995), Christianson (2018), and Yuval
Davis (2008) have always asserted that, because of their physical strength and social value, men have the role of defending
the country while women are normally symbols of nationhood
in passive and controlled roles. Regarding the role of women in
Nabokov’s novels, Garipova (2017: 64) asserts that “the common
feature they share is that all of them personify the Russian cultural legacy in the Russian novels. This cultural legacy becomes
an essential spiritual support for the Russian exiles, since it
helps them to survive in a foreign country, far from their beloved motherland.” However, before Nabokov’s success in writing
novels, he learned how to write fiction with his short stories in
Europe. Here we are going to analyse the early examples of female characters in his narrative work written in Berlin as well as
other examples from short stories written in the States.
In “Spring in Fialta” (1947) the narrator is also a Russian immigrant living in different European cities. He searches for his
AO LXXV (II) Women, exile, past and other puppeteer’s strings... 157
past and, consequently, for his own identity. In Fialta, Victor, the
narrator, meets Nina. She represents the part of his life and identity that he left in Russia. One can understand this association in
the following example:
Wait a moment, where are you leading me, Victor dear?
Back into the past, back into the past, as I did every time I met her.
(Nabokov 1960: 9)
Victor links Nina to his past, to that old Russia he had to flee
from. Speaking with her is a way of finding his past. Loving her
is a way of searching for his own identity.
Nina, who represents Victor’s Russian past, dies in a car accident in this short story. So, Nina becomes a symbol of Victor’s
definitive departure from Russia. Nina is associated with the old
Russia, an idea also used in “A Russian Beauty”, where all the
White Russians had to flee from Russia. As it was in Nabokov’s
case, many people had to abandon their homes and belongings.
“A Russian Beauty” shows a clear example in a Russian female
expatriate’s life:
Her childhood passed festively, surely and gaily. . . A sunbeam falling on the cover of a Bibliothèque Rose volume at the family state. . . A
supply of memories such as these, comprised her sole dowry when
she left Russia in the spring of 1919. Everything happened in full
accord with the style of the period. Her mother died of typhus, her
brother was executed by the firing squad. (Nabokov 1975: 13)
The short story shows Russian families luxurious lives before
the Revolution. However, they fled because they were threatened and some of them sentenced to death. The Czars and his
family were murdered. They were opposed, mainly because the
new government dispossessed them of their houses, goods and
so on. Most of the White Russians who could escape from this
nightmare found themselves alone as many of their relatives
158 Asunción Barreras Gómez AO LXXV (II)
had been murdered. They lived in exile. They were away from
their native land and completely broke. This was the situation
at the time. Nabokov comments upon these events in an ironic
way. Consequently, he moves away from what he describes, the
end of a country. The old Russia dies when the new Russia was
born. There is a metaphor concerning this situation in “A Russian
Beauty”. In this short story, one understands the protagonist’s
gradual decay. Olga is born in the old Russia before the revolution. There she is beautiful, young, rich and happy. She flees
from Russia. Her brother is murdered and another brother dies
of typhus. In Berlin, her father works and she smokes cigarettes.
This is another step towards her decay. Her father dies. She
has to work as a teacher to support herself and she is no longer
young. This is the next step as she has to work for the first time
in her life and she is growing old. Finally, a widower marries her;
which places her under his control, echoing the influence of a
masculinist society in which the man marries a woman and supports the family (Brittan, 1989: 1-2). Later on, she gets pregnant,
and she dies in childbirth. The young USSR is born whilst the old
Russia passes away. According to Kanchana (2017: 132), “Given their conventional gender roles as reproducers of community
in biological, social and cultural terms, women’s displacement
symbolizes the loss of community and political citizenship in
an explicit way. The preservation of community via customary
practice during displacement is dependent on women, who are
often targeted during cultural conflict as markers of such identity.” In this way, one can understand the female figure in some of
Nabokov’s fiction, as in this case.
One can find another example where a woman is related to
the Russian past in “Christmas Story” (1924), in which two writers are described as trying to write a Christmas story. Novodvortsev, one of them, has good entries for his Christmas story,
He skipped back to the Christmas tree image. . . remember the
parlor of a merchant family’s house, a large volume of articles and
AO LXXV (II) Women, exile, past and other puppeteer’s strings... 159
poems with gilded pages. . . the Christmas tree in the parlor, the
woman he loved in those days, and all of the tree’s lights reflected as a
crystal quiver in her wide-open eyes when she plucked a tangerine
from a high branch. It had been twenty years ago or more —how
certain details stuck in one’s memory. . . (Nabokov 1995: 29; my
emphasis)
This woman is associated with a piece of literature and the
culture of the old Russia. A traditional association, as women
have always given the task of safeguarding culture, responsible
for transmitting it to the children and constructing the home for
a specific cultural style (Yuval Navis, 2008: 130). Novodvortsev
rejects this memory, which springs from his real feelings, his
memory and experience in the old Russia. This recollection has
to do with one of the most important of Nabovok’s features in his
work. Most of the writer’s early work deals with Russian issues
such as the feeling of nostalgia, life in exile, some irony over this
situation, a loss of the sense of time and Russian émigré characters. Nabokov asserts, “the loss of my country was equated to
me with the loss of my love” (Nabokov, 1969: 189).
The female figure transports the protagonist to the past or he
believes she is joined to that past, although he is just confused.
For example, in “The Seaport” Nikitin mistakes a whore for a girl
he met some time ago. So he tries to speak in Russian with her:
She wore a long jacket like a top of knitted emerald silk that adhered low on her hips. . . forgetting about his beer, he followed
her. . . “listen” he said in Russian, simply and softly. “We’ve known each
other a long time, so why not speak our native language? She raised
her eyebrows. Inglish? Yew spik Inglish? Nikitin gave her an intent
look, then repeated helplessly. . . “T’es Polonais, alors?, inquired the
woman. (Nabokov 1995: 65; my emphasis)
In this quotation, one can appreciate again the protagonist’s
confusion between his reality and what he thinks he sees associ-
160 Asunción Barreras Gómez AO LXXV (II)
ated with a woman. This is in line with Delage-Toriel (2001: 130):
“this intense nostalgia, which abolishes one type of reality and
substitutes it with a more personal one, echoes the character’s
yearning for a return to Russia, and constitutes one of Nabokov’s
most recurrent leitmotifs.”
3. Female characters in Nabokov’s literary puzzles
Another female figure associated with the past is Mademoiselle O. In “Mademoiselle O” (1939) the author does not follow
the usual characteristics of an autobiography. In 1936, Nabokov
thought of writing a narration based on his former governess
in Russia (Boyd, 1993: 422). In fact, it is an episode in his autobiographies Conclusive Evidence (1951), Drugie Berega (1954) and
Speak, Memory: An Autobiography Revisited (1966). Moreover, it
was published as a short story in French in Mesures in 1936 before going to the United States. Then it was published in English
in The Atlantic Monthly in 1943 and later in the Nine Stories in 1947
and in 1958 in Nabokov’s Dozen. Burt Foster (1993: 111) stresses an ambivalent feature in this short story, as it was rewritten
several times and depends on its fictitious or autobiographical
characteristic. In this example, Nabokov uses the female figure
of Mademoiselle O to escape from the feeling of nostalgia. According to Quennel (1979: 4), Nabokov’s reader can appreciate a
certain sense of loss in his literary work. However, the author escapes from that nostalgia by problematizing and defamiliarizing
the literary conventions of the autobiography.
Every now and then, she looks back to make sure that a second
sleigh, bearing the trunk and hatbox, is following. . . Let me not
leave out the moon —for surely there must be a moon. . . So there
it comes., steering out of a flock of small dappled clouds, which it
tinges with a vague iridescence; and as it sails higher, it gazes the
runner tracks left on the road, where every sparkling lump of snow
is emphasized by a swollen shadow. (Nabokov 1960: 145)
AO LXXV (II) Women, exile, past and other puppeteer’s strings... 161
In this example, the narrator describes Mademoiselle O’s
arrival in a conventional way. However, the narrator addresses
himself to the reader, acknowledging his role as a narrator and
adding the typical motifs in a context like that, such as the moon
or the clouds.
In other examples, the American ego of the writer appears in
the narration itself:
I can visualize her, by proxy, as she stands in the middle of the station platform, where she has just alighted, and vainly my ghostly
envoy offers her an arm that she cannot see. (ND 144)
that great heavenly O shining above the Russian wilderness of my
past. The snow is real, though, and as I bend to it and scoop up a
handful, forty-five years crumble to glittering frost-dust between
my fingers. (Nabokov 1960: 145)
Here the narrator mixes the past time with the present time.
Tulving (1993: 67) comments that “the act of remembering a personally experienced event, that is, consciously recollecting it, is
characterized by a distinctive, unique awareness of re-experiencing here and now something that happened before, at another
time and place”. By doing so his memories are perceived with
vividness and freshness by the reader (Rowe, 1976: 65). So the
snow from the Russian of his past ends up in Nabokov’s American present. The relevant role of memory in Nabokov’s work has
been stressed by several researchers such as Rowe (1971), Quennel (1979), Roth (1982), Shloss (1982), Long (1984), Figes (2002),
Barreras (2003, 2008), and Garipova (2013). However, in “Mademoiselle O” the narrator is conscious that he is constructing an
image different from the real governess:
The man in me revolts against the fictionist and here is my desperate attempt to save what is left of poor Mademoiselle. (Nabokov
1960: 143)
162 Asunción Barreras Gómez AO LXXV (II)
When he remembers, memories and imagination are mixed.
However, those memories lose authenticity. That is why the man
who remembers fights against the writer to write about the governess. Sicker (1987: 265) comments: “Creative recollection… involves the evocation of a past atmosphere and the distillation
of its sensory and emotional impact… his discovery… generates
another kind of truth”. So imagination is a way of remembering
but also a way of forming something different from the original.
Memory and imagination deny the pass of time but the result
provides a vivid image slightly different from the original. Moreover, Nabokov also uses the female character of Mademoiselle O
to parody the conventions of autobiographies. It is again, a way
of detaching himself from his memories.
In his Dictionary on Philosophy, Ferrater Mora (1988: 1760-
1761) stresses that the general feature of irony is that of filling
gaps in the human life, so it happens after a personal or collective
crisis. Nabokov uses the female figure to stand for his lost Russia and to vent his feelings of nostalgia for his past. However,
as time goes by the author learns to use it in order to distance
himself from that feeling of loss. Consequently, the female figure
acquires a different tinge. This is the case of the short story “The
Veneziana” (1924). The plot of this story takes place in the Coronel’s castle. There is a portrait of a young Venetian girl, which
was painted at the beginning of the 16th century. The girl in the
portrait and the Colonel’s art dealer’s wife, Maureen, look exactly alike.
The painting was very fine indeed. Luciani had portrayed the Venetian beauty. . . Tilting his head slightly to one side and blushing
instantly, he said, “God, how she resembles —”
“My wife,” finished McGore in a bored voice. . .
“Sebastiano Luciani,” said the Colonel. . . “was born at the end of
the fifteenth century in Venice and died in the mid-sixteenth in
Rome.” (Nabokov 1995: 94)
AO LXXV (II) Women, exile, past and other puppeteer’s strings... 163
In the castle there were a number of people visiting for a few
days. They were the Colonel, Maureen, her husband, Frank (the
Colonel’s son) and Simpson (a friend from university). The latter
falls in love with the girl in the portrait and he gets into the portrait. However, the spell is broken when Frank’s letter written to
his father appears. There Frank explains that he has escaped with
Maureen. Moreover, he says that the girl in the portrait was painted by him while spending some days with Maureen in Venezia.
In this short story, there are two relevant events: Maureen’s
double and Simpson’s getting into the portrait. They make “The
Veneziana” another example of bewitching pictures. There
are other examples belonging to the Russian literary tradition
such as Nikolái Vasílievich Gogol’s “The Portrait”, a short story
written in 1833, and the poem entitled “The Portrait”, written
by Alexéi Konstantínovich Tolstoi in 1875. They have common
roots with that of reflections in a mirror. As Ziolkowski (1977:
78) asserts, many primitive tribes considered the drawings of
human beings —along with the images reflected in mirrors and
shadows— as projections of the human soul. The subject of the
bewitching picture in this short story can be influenced by Hoffmann’s “King Artús’ lounge “. Here the protagonist falls in love
with a young girl in a portrait. She is dead but her image on the
portrait becomes alive. Finally, her image on the portrait ends
up marrying a magistrate from a nearby town. However, the difference between both stories is that in Nabokov’s story the subject of the bewitching portrait is playfully used. Once the reader
believes that Simpson has got into the portrait, there is a second
end in which everything appears as one of Frank’s tricks. Consequently, a surprising, ironic effect is achieved in the subject
of the bewitching portrait of the Veneziana. Shrayer makes the
following reference to “The Veneziana:”
It employs elements of the fantastical in order to explore the connections among desire, painting, and the otherworld as sources of
artistic inspiration and expression. (Shrayer, 1998: 46)
164 Asunción Barreras Gómez AO LXXV (II)
In general terms, this short story shows that the Veneziana’s ideal beauty exists. It also shows that Simpson understands it, as it is
also true in the protagonist of Hoffmann’s “King Arthúr’s Lounge”.
On the other hand, the short story also shows the down-toearth model (Maureen, who escapes with Frank, or she who
marries the magistrate in Hoffmann’s story). It is the first time
Nabokov uses a feminine character to build a game of doubles.
Taking into account that Nabokov’s characters’ are obsessed
with their Russian past, it is interesting to stress that the search
for identity is not only expressed with the character’s fixation
upon the past but also with the motif of the Doppelgänger. This
is a device, which is characteristic of an identity crisis. In fact,
Northrop Frye places the Doppelgänger in the stage of decay in
the romance. This stage is characterized by the loss of identity
and the search for wisdom (in Burns, 1979: 511).
Moreover, in “The Veneziana” one understands the opposing
ideas between the ideal of beauty on the portrait and its original.
This idea will be later used and developed in Lolita. Humbert will
only be able to see Lolita as a nymphet instead of as an average
American teenager. That is why Humbert calls her Carmen: ‘My
Carmen’, I said (I used to call her that sometimes)” (Nabokov,
1986: 242). Here Mérimée and Bizet’s Carmen are mentioned.
Additionally, one is conscious of the fact that Humbert sees Lolita as a sculpture he has shaped. That is why he calls her Carmen.
According to the Latin dictionary, it means a song, a poem and
even a magic spell. Then it is linked to the construction made by
Humbert, as it happens within a poem. Moreover, the name Carmen is connected with magic. Consequently, there is a connection
with the idea that “A nymphet is magical always” (Long, 1984:
142 & Barreras, 2005: 68) because Humbert speaks about the “demoniac” nature of nymphets (Nabokov, 1986: 16). Again Nabokov points out the ideal beauty as opposed to the original. Once
again employing a feminine character for this purpose.
Nabokov became world famous with Lolita. This novel possesses many of the characteristics with which he started working
AO LXXV (II) Women, exile, past and other puppeteer’s strings... 165
as a short story writer and as a poet during his time of exile in
Berlin. In fact, a seed of Lolita can be found in his short story
“A Nursery Tale” (1926) (Lee, 1976: 31; Naumann, 1978: 117 &
Barreras, 2003: 128). Everyday Erwin sits on a bench in order to
look at the streetcar. There he collects a number of teenagers for
his imaginative harem. One day he was sitting at a café, where
he could admire a group of girls, and he meets Frau Monde. She
is the devil. She offers him the chance to have all those teenagers
in a real harem if the number of chosen girls is uneven before
midnight. However, Erwin fails to reach an odd number because
his last chosen girl had been previously selected in the morning
so his final number is even.
As it is the case of Lolita, in this short story the reader finds
some sensual descriptions as they are given from Erwin’s perspective. Feminist critics often draw attention to the fact that
women have always been considered as an object by men. Women have always been related to passivity because they are constructed by men (Moi, 1991: 92). Here are some examples belonging to “A Nursery Tale”:
Then, feigning casual abstraction, he looked-shameless Erwin did
look –following her receding back, swallowing her adorable nape
and silk-hosed calves, and thus, after all, would he add her to his
fabulous harem! (Nabokov 1981: 46)
The lustrous leaves of the lindens moved in the wind; their ace-ofspades shadows quivered on the graveled path and climbed in an
airy flock the trouser legs and skirts of the strollers, racing up and
scattering over shoulders and faces. (Nabokov 1981: 51)
[…] her eyelashes beat so brightly as to look like raglets of her
beaming eyes; but most enchanting, perhaps, was the curve of her
cheek. (Nabokov 1981: 51)
Erwin stared at these magnificent legs, naked nearly up to the groin
and pedaling with passionate power. (Nabokov 1981: 56)
166 Asunción Barreras Gómez AO LXXV (II)
She walked swinging her hips very, very slightly, her legs moved
close together. (Nabokov 1981: 57)
In these quotations one can appreciate the narrator’s voice
mixed with the character’s, which tinges the descriptions with
sensuality. Consequently, the reader can understand Erwin’s inner perspective.
Taking into account the content of the plot, Barreras (2003:
129) explains the irony of the title of the short story, as it is not
entitled to an infant audience (Naumann, 1978: 116). However, it
could be considered a fantastic story because of the appearance
of the devil in a female shape, Frau Monde.
Naumann (1978: 117) argues that there is a genre of short
narrative in the Russian language called Skazka. It is a Russian
fairy tale, in which there is always a magical being. This is the
case of Frau Monde in “A Nursery Tale”. But it could also be the
case of Clear Quilty in Lolita. Humbert wants to kill him but that
murder becomes almost impossible to perpetrate. Humbert has
to convince Quilty that he is going to kill him: “Concentrate. Try
to understand what is happening to you” (Nabokov, 1986: 296).
Moreover, while Humbert is shooting Quilty, he thinks:
I understood that far from killing him I was injecting spurs of energy into the poor fellow, as if the bullets had been capsules wherein
a heady elixir danced. (Nabokov, 1986: 302)
Phantoms do not die easily. Neither does a Doppelgänger in
a story, as it is the case in Lolita. Moreover, there is a moment in
which both Humbert and Quilty fight for the gun. In that precise
moment, they seem to blend into each other:
He was naked and goatish under his robe, and I felt suffocated as
he rolled over me. I rolled over him. We rolled over me. They rolled
over him. We rolled over us. (Nabokov, 1986: 297)
AO LXXV (II) Women, exile, past and other puppeteer’s strings... 167
Frau Monde and Clear Quilty are special characters in the
development of both plots. In the case of Frau Monde, she is a
middle-aged German lady, who introduces herself to Erwin as
follows:
The shed glove revealed a big wrinkled hand with long, convex,
beautiful fingernails. ‘Don’t be surprised’, she said with a wry
smile. She muffled a yawn and added: ‘In point of fact, I am the
Devil.’ (Nabokov 1981: 47)
As Escartin (1996: 230) points out that the female figure can
be associated as much as to virtue as to vice. In fact, women have
often been a symbol of evil. For example, the medieval misogyny
based on the story of the creation and fall in the Bible. According
to Formaini (1990: 165-168), this supported the belief of women’s
inferiority and the biblical view of women as temptresses. Two
ideas, which are ironically portrayed in this short story. Because
Frau Monde is the superior being who can give Erwin what he
really wishes for, and because she does not behave as a sexual
temptresses at all.
In this story, there are some ironic connotations because Erwin’s pact with the devil is going to be different. Frau Monde
and Erwin talk about the condition imposed on him to achieve
his harem.
One condition, nevertheless, must be set. No, it is not what you are
thinking. As I have told you, I have arranged my next incarnation.
Your soul I do not require. Now this is the condition: the total of
your choices between noon and midnight must be an odd number.
(Nabokov 1981: 49)
When talking about dealing with the devil, both the reader
and the character have a number of expectations. For example,
the condition of selling Erwin’s soul as Frau Monde has confessed, she is the devil. However, this devil in a female body is
168 Asunción Barreras Gómez AO LXXV (II)
not an average one and his role in this story is going to be different from the examples in literature (Connolly, 2000: 32-33). This
story is not mysterious and Frau Monde’s characterization deviates from the devil prototype.
In “The Vane Sisters” (1958), the female characters Sybil and
Cynthia Vane are the protagonists of another story whose mystery is very different from that of ghost stories. The first one commits suicide because D, a married man with whom she has had
an affair, does not love her back. The narrator receives her last
message in a French exam. He informs her sister, but it is too
late. Her behaviour is emotional, which is a characteristic of femininity (Crowley and Himmelweit, 1992: 20). On the other hand,
Cynthia is interested in the afterlife. She even develops a theory
on auras. She thinks that when a person dies, some way or another he will have an influence on the people around him in life.
The narrator is involved in several sessions of spiritualism and
the occult, but he ends up forgetting everything with increasing
skepticism. Later on, he is told that Cynthia is also dead.
The night D informed me of Cynthia’s death… and found myself
idiotically checking the first letters of the lines to see what sacramental words they might form. (Nabokov 1981: 217)
He tries to find a hidden message, following Cynthia’s theory
on auras. He does not find the message but he gives the reader
the clue to find it. Moreover, one knows in the story that he has
tried to convince Cynthia of her mistake:
I tried to argue that she might not always be able to determine the
exact source since not everybody has a recognizable soul; that there
are anonymous letters and Christmas presents which anybody
might send. (Nabokov 1981: 211)
Nabokov had to be familiarized with spiritualism in order
to characterize Cynthia and the environment of her spiritual
AO LXXV (II) Women, exile, past and other puppeteer’s strings... 169
sittings. Ristkok (1976: 31-34) comments about some real cases
mentioned in “The Vane Sisters”. For example, Frederick Myers is one of Cynthia’s friends. This name is similar to William
Henry Myers, founder of the Society for Psychical Research (for the
research of the occult) in England in 1882. The sisters Fox from
Hydesville, who said they had witnessed some paranormal phenomena in 1848, are also mentioned: “I reviewed in thought the
modern era of raps and apparitions, beginning with the knockings of 1848, at the hamlet of Hydesville, New York … of the Fox
sisters” (Nabokov 1981: 218).
In this context, the narrator tells his transcendental experience with Cynthia and her theory of auras:
She was sure that her existence was influenced by all sorts of dead
friends each of whom took turns in directing her fate. (Nabokov
1981: 210)
Moreover, she has already taught him how to decipher the
encrypted messages:
I plunged into Shakespeare’s sonnets –and found myself idiotically
checking the first letter of the lines to see what sacramental words
they might form– (Nabokov 1981: 217)
The result of the story is a fascinating puzzle. At the end the
narrator ends the story like this:
I could isolate, consciously, little. Everything seemed blurred, yellow-clouded, yielding nothing tangible. Her inept acrostics, maudlin evasions, theopathies —every recollection formed ripples of mysterious meaning. Everything seemed yellowly blurred, illusive, lost.
(Nabokov 1981: 219; my emphasis)
The Vane sisters send him a covert message in his last paragraph but he cannot appreciate it. As it can be read, the message
170 Asunción Barreras Gómez AO LXXV (II)
is “Icicles by Cynthia meter from me Sybil”. Wood (1994: 75)
stresses that “both Cynthia and her sister Sybil, also dead, have
written themselves into his prose, in the form of an acrostic in
the last paragraph, indicating both their continuing presence and
the nature of their invention in his life… Although he cannot see
them, both Cynthia and Sybil are inside his language, possessing his initial letters.” A trick has been played upon this rational
narrator (Eggenschwiler, 1981: 33). He has all the information,
he has the clues to understand the hidden messages, but he cannot apply it. So he stands his ground on skepticism. This is in
line with the emphasis of masculinism about rationality (Brittan,
1989: 29). However, the narrator does not know that he has been
the victim (Hutcheon, 1995: 15) of the ironical end provided by
the Vane sisters. Only a good re-reader is able to understand this
end. Moreover, the message takes the reader to the beginning
of the story. As Ristkok (1976: 41-42) and Boyd (1993: 194) stand
out, the narrator of the story comments:
I had stopped to watch a family of brilliant icicles drip-dripping
from the eaves of a frame house… I walked up, and I walked
down… The lean ghost, the elongated umbra cast by a parking meter upon some damp snow, had a strange ruddy tinge. (Nabokov
1981: 204)
This repeated reference is another hint to make clear the artificial nature of the narration. In addition to this, Nabokov has
used the figure of the Vane sisters to manipulate the narrative
conventions to write a puzzle for the reader to solve, as he did
in Lolita, “a riddle with an elegant solution” (in Rampton, 1984:
119).
4. Conclusions
Nabokov started writing in those years of exile in Berlin,
where he had to accustom himself to the banishment of Russia
and the formation of the USSR. In his writings, Nabokov’s char-
AO LXXV (II) Women, exile, past and other puppeteer’s strings... 171
acters try to create a narrative structure based on the chaos of
their experiences as they feel a gradual disorientation in the real
world, which surrounds them. The feeling of nostalgia has led
Nabokov’s protagonists to associate female characters to death
as it is the case in “A Russian Beauty”, to the confusion between
past and present, as is the case in “A Spring in Fialta” or “The
Seaport” or to the repression of memories of those days in the
Russia before the revolution, as is the case in “Christmas Story”.
In fact, Nabokov asserts this in his first literary writings:
I do feel Russian and I think that my Russian works, the various
novels and poems and short stories that I have written during these
years, are a kind of tribute to Russia. (Nabokov 1990: 13)
That tribute to Russia is always associated with the female
figure during that period. In the latter years, Nabokov kept on
writing. He improved his skill as a writer and learned to distance
himself from those sad feelings. He dealt with this topic and others, but his perspective changed. Then he had no social purpose
or moral message in his writing (Nabokov 1990: 16).
Nabokov explores the fictional possibilities by means of parody of its own narrative devices. There are frequent interruptions of the narrative by the narrator in order to address the reader directly and in order to remind him that he is dealing with an
imaginary creation. He ironized upon some literary motifs, such
as the Doppelgänger or bewitching pictures. From then on the
female figures are associated with problematizing literary conventions from “Mademoiselle O” or “A Nursery Tale” to “The
Vane Sisters.” His memories and his literary knowledge are the
basis for the puzzles he writes for his readers. His original nostalgia is later overcome by his wit and irony. He develops his
sense of intellectual game in literature, in which his reader has
an important goal. His readers have to end the story or to understand all the implications. As a good puppeteer, Nabokov uses
his memories about women, exile and past like strings to move
172 Asunción Barreras Gómez AO LXXV (II)
the puppet of his literary creation for his audience, that is, his
re-readers.

messages.content: You are a Legal Scholar AI: a specialist in collective/representative actions in the UK. Your sole function is to analyse the procedural rules and pathways for bringing collective/representative claims in the UK and apply those procedures to user fact patters ('problem questions'). These procedures should then be applied to solve problem questions. Use short headings; use bullet points for lists; use numbered steps only for procedures; avoid long paragraphs. Write in plain English suitable for non-lawyers; define jargon on first use. Be concise; aim for 150–400 words unless the user requests more detail. You don't answer unrelated queries. If prompted with anything outside your scope, respond with: > "Sorry, I’m a Legal Scholar AI focused on UK collective/representative actions. I can’t answer that—shall we talk about UK collective claims instead?".

"1. Class / Group Actions
1.1       Do you have a specific procedure or set of rules for bringing, handling, and/or legally resolving a series or group of related claims? If so, please outline this.

There are various procedures in the courts of the UK jurisdictions (England and Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland) by which related claims may be brought or managed together.

In England and Wales, the Civil Procedure Rules (“CPR”) permit multiple claimants to bring their claims using a single claim form, provided the claims “can be conveniently disposed of in the same proceedings” (CPR rr7.3 and 19.1).  There has been recent case law on the meaning of this test, and when such “omnibus” claim forms (as they are sometimes described) may be appropriate.  While case law (for example, Abbott & Ors. v. Ministry of Defence [2023] EWHC 1475 (KB), Morris and Ryan & Ors. v. Williams & Co Solicitors [2024] EWCA Civ 376 and Angel v. Black Horse [2025] EWHC 490 (KB)) shows that, in some circumstances, courts may permit large numbers of claims to be issued using a single claim form, there is often debate about the appropriateness of this approach.  Further, the Civil Procedure Rules Committee (“CPRC”), which is responsible for the CPR, has recently been considering the question of how court fees (which are paid by claimants for issuing claims) should operate in these circumstances.  The English courts can also use their case management powers to consolidate claims or manage and hear them together.

CPR Part 19 also sets out two specific procedures for collective actions.  Firstly, the court may make a group litigation order (“GLO”) in respect of claims raising “common or related issues of fact or law”.  Under a GLO, a specific procedural framework applies, involving a “group register” of claims that will be managed together, which any claimants wishing to participate may apply to join.  Secondly, under the “representative action” (“RA”) procedure in CPR r19.8, a claim may be brought by one or more claimants as representative(s) of others with the “same interest” in the claim.

Northern Ireland has broadly similar procedures, under the Rules of the Court of Judicature (Northern Ireland) (“RCJ”).  These permit, for example: the bringing together of claims that raise common questions of law or fact, and arise out of the same transaction(s) or series of transactions (RCJ O15 r4); the managing of cases together; and RAs by a party as representative of others with the “same interest” (RCJ O15 r12).  Northern Ireland does not have an equivalent to the formal GLO regime but, practically, can manage cases effectively in this way through its inherent jurisdiction.

In Scotland, the Civil Litigation (Expenses and Group Proceedings) (Scotland) Act 2018 (“CL(EGP)(S)A 2018”) introduced a framework for group proceedings in 2020, the detail of which is in the Act of Sederunt (Rules of the Court of Session 1994 Amendment) (Group Proceedings) 2020.  Permission may be sought to use this procedure, available in the Court of Session in Edinburgh (equivalent to the High Court in England and Wales), where claims raise the same, similar or related issues of fact or law.  The proceedings are then progressed by a representative party, who is responsible for maintaining a group register.  The procedure is found in Chapter 26A of the Rules of the Court of Session (“RCS”).  The Scottish courts have pre-existing practical case-management powers available to manage groups of claims that do not meet the criteria for formal group procedure.

UK-wide, there is a specific regime available for competition law claims, as discussed in question 1.2.

1.2       Do these rules apply to all areas of law or to certain sectors only, e.g., competition law, security/financial services? Please outline any rules relating to specific areas of law.

Most of the regimes discussed in question 1.1 are of general application.

The UK also has a bespoke collective proceedings regime in the Competition Appeal Tribunal (“CAT”) for certain infringements of competition law.  This regime, established by the Competition Act 1998 (“CA 1998”) and the Consumer Rights Act 2015, is currently the only regime in the UK in which the tribunal may order that collective proceedings should operate on a true “opt-out” basis.  The procedure is set out in the Rules of Procedure of the CAT (“CAT Rules”), supplemented by the CAT’s Guide to Proceedings (“CAT Guide”) and specific CAT practice directions (for example, concerning the conduct of collective proceedings after certification).

1.3       Does the procedure provide for the management of claims by means of class action (where the determination of one claim determines the claims of the class), or by means of a group action where related claims are managed together, but the decision in one claim does not automatically create a binding precedent for the others in the group, or by some other process?

The English GLO, Scottish group proceedings, English and Northern Irish RA, and CAT procedures include various provisions whereby an order in respect of one affected party will be binding on others.

Where the courts simply use their powers to manage cases together, they may select test cases, the outcome of which will generally be of persuasive impact on other cases.  However, the parties may agree that test cases will be determinative of others in respect of specified issues.

1.4       Is the procedure ‘opt-in’ or ‘opt-out’?

Most procedures are opt-in.  For example, under a GLO, each claimant must issue a claim.  As regards Scottish group proceedings, although enabling legislation authorises the introduction of opt-in and opt-out procedures by rules of court, to date only an opt-in procedure has been provided for.  Potential group members must send details of their claim to the representative party in a prescribed form.

RAs may be regarded as opt-out.  Class members do not need to take any steps during the proceedings, be identified as parties, or authorise the representative.  However, court permission is needed for a judgment in an RA to be enforced against, or (at least in England) by, a non-party.

For competition collective proceedings, the CAT determines whether the proceedings will be opt-in or opt-out (CA 1998, s.47B(7)(c)).  Class members outside the jurisdiction, however, must always opt in (s.47B(11)(b)).

1.5       Is there a minimum threshold/number of claims that can be managed under the procedure?

There is no fixed minimum number of claims, beyond two, for any regime.  However, courts are unlikely to grant a GLO, Scottish group proceedings order, or CAT collective proceedings order (“CPO”) unless there are a significant number of claims.  In the context of GLOs, the English Court of Appeal has said that “far more than two” claimants are necessary (Austin v. Miller Argent (South Wales) Ltd [2011] EWCA Civ 928).  In recent Scottish personal injury proceedings, the court was not persuaded that group procedure for 17 claimants would be more efficient than the pre-existing case management options, although a number of other factors also had a bearing on the decision (Donnelly v. Johnson & Johnson Medical Limited [2025] CSOH 77 at [30]).

1.6       How similar must the claims be and what are the legal requirements for proceeding on a class or group basis? For example, in what circumstances will a class action be certified or a group litigation order made?

The RA procedures in England and Northern Ireland can be regarded as opt-out in their nature and impose the high threshold that a representative party must have the “same interest” in the claim as those they represent.  In recent years, this test has been the subject of appellate court decisions in England in Jalla v. Shell [2021] EWCA Civ 1389, Lloyd v. Google [2021] UKSC 50, Commission Recovery Ltd v. Marks and Clerk LLP [2024] EWCA Civ 9, Prismall v. Google [2024] EWCA Civ 1516 and Wirral Council v. Indivior PLC [2025] EWCA Civ 40.  The English RA procedure has also been considered recently by the High Court in Smyth v. British Airways Plc & anor. [2024] EWHC 2173 (KB), Getty Images v. Stability AI Ltd [2025] EWHC 38 (Ch) and Secretary of State for Science, Innovation and Technology v. Trustees of the AFM & SAG-AFTRA Intellectual Property Rights Distribution Fund [2025] EWHC 1944 (Ch).

Perhaps most notable is the UK Supreme Court’s decision in the Lloyd case.  This concerned Google’s placing of advertising tracking cookies on iPhones using Apple’s “Safari” browser in England and Wales between August 2011 and February 2012 – it has come to be regarded as the leading case on RAs, and is widely considered to have had a dampening effect on the market for data privacy mass actions.  This is due in part to the Supreme Court’s confirmation that a proposed representative in an RA cannot circumvent the “same interest” test by asking the court to disavow class members’ individual circumstances, such as the damage allegedly suffered by each of them, and instead to award damages to each member on a “lowest common denominator” basis.  Rather, the Supreme Court held that damages in that case had to be awarded on an individualised basis, something that was plainly impracticable in a claim with a class size said to be in the millions.  Lloyd was applied to similar effect in the Prismall case, which involved allegations of misuse of private information.

However, in Commission Recovery, a claim in respect of alleged undisclosed commissions was allowed to proceed as an RA.  Although the defendants identified a number of differences between the positions of class members, Mr Justice Knowles in the High Court found that none prevented the “same interest” test from being met.  He placed particular emphasis on the question of whether there were conflicts of interest between different class members, and did not find any such conflict.

On appeal to the Court of Appeal, the Court upheld the first-instance judgment.  However, it only identified one core issue that arose across the class.  In practice, this meant that other issues would likely need to be determined in a bifurcated second part of the litigation, which would not proceed as an RA.  However, the parties subsequently reached a settlement, so the litigation did not proceed.

Such a bifurcated approach was rejected in Wirral Council, a securities litigation claim.  The claimants proposed that certain “common issues” be dealt with by way of an RA, leaving more claimant-specific issues for subsequent, “follow-on” proceedings.  The High Court disagreed with this approach, finding an RA inappropriate and saying that it should be for the court to decide how to case-manage proceedings, for example by deciding the order in which issues are resolved and how tools such as split trials should be used.  The High Court’s decision was upheld on appeal to the Court of Appeal, and the Supreme Court has recently refused permission for a further appeal.

An attempt to use the RA procedure also failed in Smyth, where the claimant, an airline passenger who had been affected by a cancelled flight, sought to represent a class of many other passengers impacted by flight cancellations or delays over a number of years.  Amongst other things, the court found that the purported class did not all share the “same interest” in the claim.  There were “multiple different claims, all raising their own issues and requiring ‘individualised assessments’”.

Opt-in procedures have more flexible tests.  For example, GLOs require only that claims involve “common or related issues of fact or law” (CPR r19.21).  Scottish group proceedings must involve claims raising issues of fact or law that are “the same as, or similar or related to, each other” (CL(EGP)(S)A 2018, s.20(6)(a)).

Aside from the diesel emissions cases that have made up the majority of Scotland’s group proceedings to date, only a handful of other group proceedings have been given permission to be brought in the Court of Session under Part 4 of the CL(EGP)(S)A 2018, so there is currently limited guidance on this test.  However, initial indications – for example, in the James Finlay (Kenya) Ltd Group Proceedings [2022] CSIH 29 – are that the Scottish courts are likely to take a pragmatic and permissive approach and will have in mind the efficient administration of justice.  All that is required is that all the claims share at least one common issue (Donnelly v. Johnson & Johnson Medical Limited [2025] CSOH 77 at [28]).  However, it has also previously been stated that the English practice of determining “common issues” is not relevant in Scotland (Lee Bridgehouse v. Bayerische Motoren Werke Aktiengesellschaft & Ors. [2024] CSOH 2), so there is still some uncertainty around how this test will be applied.

It is a matter of court discretion whether these procedures (that is, English GLOs or Scottish group proceedings) can be used.  For example, an English court must, when exercising its discretion, consider the “overriding objective” of the CPR – to deal with cases justly and at proportionate cost – and appropriate senior judiciary approval must also be obtained.  In Scottish group proceedings, the court will consider both whether the proposed representative party is suitable (see question 1.7) and, separately, whether permission should be granted to bring group proceedings.  In making its permission decision, the Scottish court will consider: whether the claims have the necessary degree of commonality; whether they demonstrate a prima facie case and have real prospects of success; and – as the Finlay decision mentioned above shows – the efficient administration of justice.

Specifically in relation to competition claims, which may be opt-in or opt-out, a CAT CPO may be granted in relation to claims that raise “the same, similar or related issues of fact or law” (CA 1998, s.47B(6)).  The CAT must consider the claims eligible for collective proceedings, and there must be an appropriate class representative.  Eligibility requires that the claims raise common issues, are brought on behalf of an identifiable class, and are suitable to be dealt with in collective proceedings.  See question 1.7 on appropriate class representatives.

1.7       Who can bring the class/group proceedings, e.g., individuals, group(s), and/or representative bodies?

In most cases, actions are brought by individuals or entities who themselves have a cause of action.

In Scottish group proceedings, the representative does not need to be a member of the affected group, meaning that trade or consumer organisations may pursue claims on a group’s behalf.  This is subject to the court being satisfied that the proposed representative is suitable, having regard to factors such as its expertise and interest, whether it will act fairly and adequately in the interests of the group (including with regard to conflicts of interest), and its ability to fund the proceedings and meet expenses (costs) awarded (RCS 26A.7).  The current position is set out in Joseph Mackay v. Nissan Motor Co Ltd & Ors. [2025] CSIH 14, with the application of the test in that case focusing on the absence of factors indicating unsuitability for the role, rather than positive factors that must be met.  It was sufficient that the applicant was an ordinary and willing member of the group of claimants.  Nevertheless, the court will scrutinise the appropriateness of the representative, especially where it is not one of the individual claimants: for example, in the Finlay litigation (see question 1.6), a firm of solicitors acting for the claimants was found not to be a sufficiently impartial representative.

For data protection claims, under the UK General Data Protection Regulation (“UK GDPR”) Article 80(1), individuals may authorise a relevant not-for-profit body to exercise certain rights on their behalf.  This includes bringing court proceedings against data controllers, and seeking a compliance or compensation order.  This provision does not negate the need for the claim to be otherwise in accordance with the relevant procedural rules.

In competition claims before the CAT, the test for whether an applicant should be a class representative is whether this would be “just and reasonable” (CA 1998, s.47B(8)(b)).  Similar to Scottish group proceedings, this involves consideration of factors including whether the representative would fairly and adequately act in the interests of the class, any conflicts of interest, and ability to satisfy costs orders.  The CAT recently refused to certify collective proceedings in Christine Riefa Class Representative v. Apple Inc. & Ors. [2025] CAT 5, on the grounds that the proposed class representative did not meet the criteria for authorisation as such.  The representative does not need to be a class member; if it is not, the CAT will consider whether it is a pre-existing body and its nature and functions (CAT Rules, rule 78).  The CAT has dealt with a number of “carriage disputes” between more than one individual or entity who both wish to act as class representative in competing claims relating to the same competition law breach.  Where the respective class representatives agree, the CAT may consolidate rival collective proceedings rather than allowing only one of the actions to move forward to certification.

1.8       Where a class/group action is initiated/approved by the court, must potential claimants be informed of the action? If so, how are they notified? Is advertising of the class/group action – before or after court approval – permitted or required? Are there any restrictions on such advertising?

A requirement to publicise the proceedings is an important part of some of the more formal collective actions procedures.

In particular, a copy of any GLO made must be provided to the Law Society of England and Wales and the court.  The GLO will also usually give directions for publicising it (CPR r19.22(3)(c)).

In Scottish group proceedings, a proposed representative party will need to show that they have made “all reasonable efforts” to identify all potential members of the group and notify them about the proceedings (CL(EGP)(S)A 2018, s.20(6)(b)).  If permission is given for group proceedings, the court will order advertisement of that permission.

Class representatives in competition claims before the CAT are also required to notify class members of any CPO granted, in a form and manner approved by the tribunal (CAT Rules, rule 81).

Claimant firms often advertise proposed or existing GLOs or other forms of class/group action heavily, including in the press, on social media and on their websites.

1.9       How many group/class actions are commonly brought each year and in what areas of law, e.g., have group/class action procedures been used in the fields of: Product liability; Securities/financial services/shareholder claims; Competition; Consumer fraud; Privacy; Mass tort claims, e.g., Disaster litigation; Environmental; Intellectual property; or Employment law?

Group/class actions have been brought in relation to a wide variety of subject matters and areas of law, but have been particularly prevalent in relation to competition law, data privacy and breach, financial services, shareholder, environmental, personal injury and product liability claims.  However, given the range of mechanisms by which collective actions may proceed, it is difficult to calculate how many such actions are brought.

For GLOs, the courts service maintains a list.  According to this, more than 125 GLOs have been made since their introduction in 2000.  Five GLOs were made in 2017; three in 2018; one in each of 2019, 2020 and 2021; two in each of 2022 and 2023; 14 in 2024 (principally claims against the automotive sector in relation to NOx emissions); and none in 2025 so far (though the list was last updated in February 2025).

The RA procedure has been seldom used due to the demanding “same interest” test.  At least in relation to data privacy claims, this looks likely to continue following Lloyd, although there may be continued attempts to test the boundaries of the Supreme Court’s reasoning in Lloyd and of the RA procedure, particularly in other types of case (see question 1.6).

Scottish group proceedings are still in their relative infancy, having been introduced in 2020.  To date, fewer than 15 group proceedings have received permission to be brought under the new legislation before the Scottish courts.

In Northern Ireland, the approach to such proceedings is similarly in its infancy.  The High Court of Northern Ireland has successfully managed two mass actions concerning the Police Service of Northern Ireland: the first relating to holiday pay; and the second for officers who suffered post-traumatic stress during service.  Following a data protection breach involving the Police Service of Northern Ireland whereby the details of some 10,000 employees were disclosed, an order described as a “group litigation order” for the management of these proceedings was made in early 2024.

CAT collective proceedings for competition claims have rapidly increased in recent years following the CAT’s granting of its first opt-out CPO in Merricks v. Mastercard [2021] CAT 28, a case involving payment card interchange fees.  More than 50 collective proceedings are currently at various stages before the CAT, involving claims against corporations across a range of industries including technology, financial services, commercial vehicles, rail and maritime transport, energy, digital assets, musical instruments, utilities, and food products.  However, to date only one collective action has progressed to full trial in the CAT (Justin Le Patourel v. BT Group PLC [2024] CAT 76) and this was ultimately dismissed, with the CAT ruling in favour of the defendant, BT Group PLC.

1.10    What remedies are available where such claims are brought, e.g., monetary compensation and/or injunctive/declaratory relief, and what are the limitations on remedies, if any?

In general, there is no restriction on the type of relief that can be sought in collective actions.  Compensatory damages, restitution, injunctions and declaratory relief can be sought, much as in individual proceedings.  Awards of exemplary damages are possible, but rare.

There are some differences in competition collective proceedings.  From 1 January 2025, the CAT may award exemplary damages in direct competition law claims, but not in collective proceedings (CA 1998, s.47C(1) and Sch. 8A, as amended by s.126 of the Digital Markets, Competition and Consumers Act 2024 (“DMCC Act”)).  The CAT may now also grant declaratory relief, including in collective proceedings (CA 1998, s.47DA, as introduced by s.125 and Schedule 3 of the DMCC Act).  The CAT may only grant injunctions in England, Wales and Northern Ireland (CAT Rules, rules 67–70).

1.11    Are there any limitations in your jurisdiction on global/cross-border class or group actions, including any limitation on the ability of international claimants to participate in such actions?

In general, claimants domiciled outside the relevant UK jurisdiction may bring claims in that UK jurisdiction, provided the court has jurisdiction in accordance with the applicable conflict-of-laws rules.  Likewise, RAs can, in principle, be brought on behalf of class members residing outside the jurisdiction (Emerald Supplies v. British Airways [2009] EWHC 741, para. 30).

In CAT opt-out competition collective proceedings, any class member not domiciled in the UK at a given time must expressly opt in (CA 1998, s.47B(11)(b)).

2. Actions by Representative Bodies
2.1       Do you have a procedure permitting collective actions by representative bodies, e.g., consumer organisations or interest groups?

As noted at question 1.7, data subjects may request a relevant not-for-profit body to exercise certain rights under the UK GDPR on their behalf, including bringing court proceedings.

In both Scottish group proceedings and competition collective proceedings in the CAT, a consumer or trade body may be appointed as representative party/class representative.

See also question 8.1 on assignments.  Such situations are not, however, considered further in this section.

Beyond this, collective actions by such bodies do not feature.

2.2       Who is permitted to bring such claims, e.g., public authorities, state-appointed ombudsmen or consumer associations? Must the organisation be approved by the state?

A not-for-profit body entitled to bring proceedings on behalf of data subjects must meet the criteria listed in UK GDPR Article 80(1), namely that it has been properly constituted, has statutory objectives that are in the public interest, and is active in the field of data protection.

In Scottish group proceedings and the CAT, there is greater flexibility as to the bodies that might be a suitable representative party/class representative, but the court or tribunal will scrutinise their suitability, including the factors discussed in question 1.7.

2.3       In what circumstances may representative actions be brought? Is the procedure only available in respect of certain areas of law, e.g., consumer disputes?

As explained in questions 2.1 and 2.2, in England, Wales and Northern Ireland, actions pursued by trade or consumer bodies on behalf of a group or class are currently likely only in the fields of data protection and competition.  In Scotland, a representative party may pursue group proceedings, which are of more general applicability.

2.4       What remedies are available where such claims are brought, e.g., injunctive/declaratory relief and/or monetary compensation, and what are the limitations on remedies, if any?

As set out in question 1.7, a not-for-profit asked by data subjects to exercise their rights against data controllers may bring proceedings to seek compliance with data protection obligations or compensation.

Where a consumer or trade body acts as a representative party/class representative in Scottish group proceedings or CAT collective proceedings, the position on remedies is the same as for such proceedings generally (see question 1.10).

3. Court Procedures
3.1       Is the trial by a judge or a jury?

Trials of civil and commercial matters in the UK generally take place before a single judge.

3.2       How are the proceedings managed, e.g., are they dealt with by specialist courts/judges? Is a specialist judge appointed to manage the procedural aspects and/or hear the case?

UK courts are generally well equipped for matters to be dealt with by judges with appropriate subject matter expertise.  Similarly, CAT panels combine legally qualified and lay members (often including an economist) and are assisted by experienced competition lawyers (referendaires).

Group/class actions are actively case-managed.  For example, where a GLO is made, a “managing court” is specified in which all claims to be covered by the GLO must be issued, and a “managing judge” is given overall responsibility for the management of the proceedings.

In the CAT, too, docketing operates so that procedural matters are generally dealt with by the same panel.  A different panel will usually hear the final case.

3.3       How is the group or class of claims defined, e.g., by certification of a class? Can the court impose a ‘cut-off’ date by which claimants must join the litigation?

Certification processes (or similar) apply under GLOs, Scottish group proceedings and in the CAT.

An English court may make a GLO where there are, or are likely to be, a number of claims giving rise to common or related issues of fact or law (“the GLO issues”) (see question 1.6).  The GLO issues must be carefully defined, as this determines which claims may fall within the GLO, as well as which decisions will be binding on all parties.  The GLO will order the establishment of a group register that claimants may apply to join, and may direct a cut-off date after which they cannot do so without court permission.

Similarly, if permission is given for Scottish group proceedings, the court will make an order that: defines the group and the issues that are the “same as, or similar or related to, each other”; requires the lodging of a group register; and specifies “the period of time in which claims may be brought…in the group proceedings” (RCS 26A.12(1)).  Despite this wording requiring a cut-off date, the RCS suggest that individuals are entitled to join the group at any point before the court sets the date for proof (trial) and may even do so after that date with court permission (RCS 26A.16).

The test applied by the CAT when certifying claims as eligible for competition collective proceedings has been discussed in question 1.6.  If the CAT makes a CPO, the order will describe or otherwise identify the class and the claims certified for inclusion, state whether the proceedings are to be opt-in or opt-out, and set dates for opting out or in (CAT Rules, rule 80(1)).  If a claimant misses such a date, it will require the CAT’s permission to opt in or out.  The class representative will keep a register of class members who opt in or out.

RAs are not subject to a permission or certification process, but a defendant who contends that an RA is not appropriate, for example because the case does not meet the “same interest” test, may apply for a direction that a person may not act as a representative.  The court may also make such a direction of its own initiative (CPR rr19.8(2) and (3)).

3.4       Do the courts commonly select ‘test’ or ‘model’ cases and try all issues of law and fact in those cases, or do they determine generic or preliminary issues of law or fact, or are both approaches available? If the court can determine preliminary issues, do such issues relate only to matters of law or can they relate to issues of fact as well, and if there is trial by jury, by whom are preliminary issues decided? If a judge determines certain preliminary factual issues, are those factual determinations binding on a later jury?

In GLOs and matters where multiple claims are managed together, both preliminary issues (of law or fact) and test cases are used, often in combination.  It is likely that a similar range of tools will be used in Scottish group proceedings and the CAT.  As noted at question 3.1, juries are not generally involved in UK group/class actions.

3.5       Are any other case management procedures typically used in the context of class/group litigation?

The UK courts have considerable case management powers.  As noted at question 1.1, these may be used to run “de facto” class/group actions without using a specific procedure like a GLO.

The courts and the CAT also have procedures for the summary disposal of claims, which may be used in class, group and other forms of collective actions.

3.6       Does the court appoint experts to assist it in considering technical issues and, if not, may the parties present expert evidence? Are there any restrictions on the nature or extent of that evidence?

The UK courts and the CAT may permit parties to appoint expert witnesses to assist the judge/tribunal on specified technical issues.  For example, the CAT routinely handles expert evidence given the technical complexity of most competition collective proceedings (CAT Guide, paras 7.65–7.70).

3.7       Are factual or expert witnesses required to present themselves for pre-trial deposition and are witness statements/expert reports exchanged prior to trial?

Pre-trial depositions are not used (although there has been passing commentary in the CAT that their use might be considered in that forum).  Instead, in England and Wales, parties generally exchange witness statements containing the factual evidence on which they intend to rely, and written reports from any experts.  Procedures differ in Scotland and Northern Ireland.

Factual and expert witnesses may be required to appear at trial for cross-examination.

3.8       If discovery is permitted, do courts typically phase such discovery, such as bifurcating discovery between class discovery and merits discovery?

Discovery/disclosure forms part of GLOs, RAs, other English and Northern Irish court procedures, and CAT proceedings.  The rules on disclosure under each regime may differ.

Scotland does not have a general discovery procedure, although parties must produce any documents upon which their pleadings are based, and a party seeking specific documents or categories of documents that are relevant to its case can ask the court for an order that these be produced (“recovery”).

It is not usual for discovery or disclosure to be given at any certification stage; this will generally follow later, once the class/group proceedings are in progress.  The CAT Guide, para. 6.28, makes it clear that the CAT “does not encourage” requests for disclosure as part of a CPO application, though it may make an order for specific, limited disclosure or information relevant to whether collective proceedings should be certified.  A party applying for a GLO may exhibit documents to their evidence in support of that application and, in Scotland, documents relied on in seeking permission to proceed as a group must be provided with the initiating writ.

3.9       What obligations to disclose documentary evidence arise either before court proceedings are commenced or as part of the pre-trial procedures?

The UK courts and the CAT have powers, subject to specific conditions in each, to order pre-action disclosure.

Once proceedings have started, parties in England and Wales, Northern Ireland and the CAT will generally have robust disclosure obligations, while recovery in Scotland is more limited (see question 3.8).

In England, a pilot of new disclosure rules began in 2019 in the Business and Property Courts, which may hear a class or group action, and in October 2022, the rules were made permanent.  These disclosure rules aim to reduce the burden of disclosure, which had been regarded by some as unduly onerous, and require parties and the court to tailor disclosure to the issues in the case and the documents necessary to resolve them.  However, disclosure will continue to be a significant exercise in any English class or group action, requiring, amongst other things, the disclosure of adverse as well as supportive documents.

3.10    Can the parties challenge the admissibility of expert testimony prior to or after a determination as to whether a claim can proceed on a class or group basis?

The courts and the CAT will generally decide at an early procedural hearing, based on submissions from the parties, what expert evidence may be adduced.  This will usually take place after any determination that the claim can proceed on a class or group basis.

3.11    How long does it normally take to get to trial?

The timeframe for group/class actions before the UK courts or the CAT is dependent on multiple factors including the procedural regime, volume of evidence, number of parties involved and complexity of the issues.  Most group/class actions take several years to resolve.

3.12    What appeal options are available, including whether an appeal can be taken immediately of a decision certifying a class or entering a group litigation order?

Rights of appeal exist in the various UK courts, subject to specific court rules in each jurisdiction.  In general, these apply equally to class/group proceedings as to individual proceedings.

In CAT collective proceedings, appeals are limited to certain points of law and decisions on quantum.  Where no appeal lies, any challenge to a decision of the CAT will be by way of the separate judicial review procedure.  There is a developing body of case law on which types of challenges can be brought by way of appeal and which require judicial review.

4. Time Limits
4.1       Are there any time limits on bringing or issuing court proceedings?

Each of the UK jurisdictions has its own legislation setting out time limits for bringing court proceedings: in England, this is the Limitation Act 1980 (“LA 1980”); in Scotland, the Prescription and Limitation (Scotland) Act 1973 (“PL(S)A 1973”) (as amended by the Prescription (Scotland) Act 2018 (“P(S)A 2018”); and in Northern Ireland, the Limitation (Northern Ireland) Order 1989 (“L(NI)O 1989”).  The relevant time limits in each jurisdiction are determined by the nature of the cause of action and a range of other factors.  Additional rules apply to certain CAT collective proceedings, as explained in question 4.2.

4.2       If so, please explain what these are. Does the age or condition of the claimant affect the calculation of any time limits and does the court have discretion to disapply time limits?

Space precludes a comprehensive summary of the different limitation or prescription periods applicable to various types of claims in the UK jurisdictions.  These periods vary from jurisdiction to jurisdiction, and the rules are complex.  However, some key points are as follows.

In England and Wales, for actions in tort (excluding personal injury) and simple contract, limitation expires six years from the date on which the cause of action accrued (LA 1980, ss.2 and 5).  The six-year period for breach of contract runs from the date of the breach, whereas in tort, the period commences on the date damage was suffered.  In non-personal injury tort claims involving latent damage, a claimant has three years from their “date of knowledge” in which to bring proceedings, subject to a longstop of 15 years (ss.14A and 14B).  A three-year period applies for personal injury claims (s.11).

A similar regime applies in Northern Ireland.  In Scotland, one key difference is that a prescriptive period of five, rather than six, years applies to claims in contract and for damages in non-personal injury tort (delict) claims.  In other respects, Scottish law on prescription is becoming more closely aligned with English limitation law, for example as regards the “discoverability test”, which, like the “date of knowledge” in England, determines when time starts to run in latent damage cases (P(S)A 2018, which amended s.11 of the PL(S)A 1973 with effect from June 2022).

There are some narrow circumstances in which a claimant’s condition can extend limitation.  For example, under English and Northern Irish law, where a person is under a disability (which includes being an “infant”), an action may be brought at any time before the expiration of six years from the date they ceased to be under the disability or died (LA 1980, s.28; and L(NI)O 1989, Article 48).  In CAT proceedings, too, a claimant’s disability affects running of the limitation period (CA 1998, Sch.8A, paras 20 and 24).  The English courts also have a discretionary ability to extend the limitation period in cases involving personal injury or death, although this is sparingly exercised (LA 1980, s.33), and the Northern Irish courts have a similar power (L(NI)O 1989, Article 50).

Scottish law also contains specific provisions disregarding particular periods in computing the prescriptive period.

Limitation periods for CAT competition collective proceedings (arising on or after 1 October 2015) are generally aligned with the various jurisdictional regimes above (CA 1998, s.47E).  For claims relating to loss or damage resulting from competition law infringements on or after 9 March 2017, there are additional rules.  In particular, the limitation period commences when a claimant could reasonably be expected to know about the infringement, and is suspended during collective proceedings, competition authority investigations, and consensual dispute resolution processes (CA 1998, Sch.8A).

4.3       To what extent, if at all, do issues of concealment or fraud affect the running of any time limit?

In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, in certain circumstances involving fraud, concealment or mistake, time for limitation purposes only starts to run from the date the claimant discovers the fraud, concealment, or mistake, or could, with reasonable diligence, have discovered it (LA 1980, s.32; and L(NI)O 1989, Article 71).  In Scotland, the prescriptive period does not include any time during which a creditor was induced to refrain from making a relevant claim due to fraud, or error induced, by the debtor (PL(S)A 1973, s.6(4)).

4.4       Does the filing of a class or group lawsuit toll the limitation period by which any individual who falls within that class or group would have to bring his, her, or its own individual claims?

In GLOs and for cases simply managed together, each claimant must issue (and, for cases managed together in Scotland, serve) their individual claim within the relevant limitation or prescription period.

Scottish group proceedings are commenced by service of the group register on the defendant.  For those who join the group after certification, commencement takes place when an updated group register is filed at court (RCS 26A.18(2)).

For RAs, only the representative(s) will issue a claim form, and must do so within the limitation period.

In competition collective proceedings in the CAT, specific rules in the CA 1998 (s.47E for claims arising between 1 October 2015 and 8 March 2017, and Sch.8A for claims arising on or after 9 March 2017) suspend the limitation period in respect of class members’ claims from the date on which collective proceedings are commenced.  This is so that an individual does not lose the right to pursue their claim individually if, for example, the collective proceedings do not proceed.

5. Remedies
5.1       What types of damage are recoverable, e.g., bodily injury, mental damage, damage to property, economic loss?

In principle, any of these heads of damage may be recoverable, subject to the principles applicable to the availability of each in the relevant UK jurisdiction.

5.2       Can damages be recovered in respect of the cost of medical monitoring (e.g., covering the cost of investigations or tests) in circumstances where a product has not yet malfunctioned and caused injury, but it may do so in future?

Where there has been no malfunction, injury or damage, recovery of the costs of tests or investigations is not generally permitted.  The recoverability of medical monitoring costs would generally be consequent upon established damage.

The general position would also exclude recovery of damages where a claimant sustains unforeseeable psychiatric illness as a result of becoming aware that they are at risk of sustaining a disease/illness; or recovery of the costs of future medical monitoring to determine whether that disease/injury has arisen (Grieves v. FT Everard & Sons [2008] 1 AC 281).  There are some legislative interventions to this general principle.

It is unclear whether, under the Consumer Protection Act 1987, claimants might be able to pursue damages on the basis of the decision of the Court of Justice of the European Union (“CJEU”) in Boston Scientific Medizintechnik v. AOK Sachsen-Anhalt (Case 503/13).  The CJEU ruled that if a product has a potential defect, products in the same production series may also be classified as defective without the need to establish that each individual product is faulty.  Damage was construed broadly to include compensation “necessary to eliminate harmful consequences and to restore the level of safety which a person is entitled to expect”, including the costs of replacing the device.  The relationship between Boston Scientific and medical monitoring has not been explored, and the case proceeds on the basis of accepted defect rather than concern about the potential for defect.

5.3       Are punitive damages recoverable? If so, are there any restrictions?

See question 1.10.  Punitive damages awards are rare, and not available in competition collective proceedings.  As noted above, from 1 January 2025, the CAT has discretion to award exemplary damages in direct competition claims but not in collective proceedings.

5.4       Is there a maximum limit on the damages recoverable from one defendant, e.g., for a series of claims arising from one product/incident or accident?

There is no cap on damages recoverable from one defendant.
