Such arrangements are not permissible in Northern Ireland, as Article 64(2)(b) of the Solicitors (Northern Ireland) Order 1976 invalidates “any agreement by which a solicitor retained or employed to prosecute any action or other contentious proceeding, stipulates for payment only in the event of success in that action or proceeding”.

In the CAT, as a general rule, conditional fee arrangements are permitted for both opt-in and opt-out collective proceedings, but DBAs are only permitted for opt-in collective proceedings (CA 1998, s.47C(8)).

7.4       Is third-party funding of claims permitted and, if so, on what basis may funding be provided?

In England, Wales and Scotland, third-party litigation funding is permitted for all types of class/group action, and, particularly in England and Wales, has generally been seen as an important way of funding such actions.  It is often combined with ATE insurance and/or the types of fee arrangements discussed in question 7.3.  In Northern Ireland, a legislative framework for third-party litigation funding has been implemented by the Access to Justice (Northern Ireland) Order 2003.  However, whilst legislative provision has been made for such funding, its practical application is still under consideration.  In In the Matter of James Craig Best (in bankruptcy) ([2024] NIMaster 3), the Master noted that Counsel “could not direct me to any legal or evidential basis upon which this court could properly conclude that such funding agreements are in use in Northern Ireland….the testing of such funding arrangements is not a matter for this court but rather for a wider consultation process and possibly legislation”.

Third-party litigation funding has been an important feature of the growing competition collective proceedings regime in the CAT.  The CAT will examine funding agreements as part of the CPO process, to ensure they are satisfactory to enable the proposed class representative to fairly and adequately act in the interests of the class and to be able to pay the defendant’s recoverable costs if ordered to do so (CAT Rules, rule 78).  Defendants may seek to challenge the adequacy of funding agreements, and/or ATE insurance, in order to persuade the CAT against granting a CPO.  The CAT has, however, exercised its discretion to refuse disclosure of strategically sensitive aspects of funding agreements and ATE insurance to defendants where such disclosure could give the defendant an unfair tactical advantage (for example, potentially revealing the class representative’s assessment of the likely prospects of success).

Against this backdrop, however, a decision of the UK Supreme Court in 2023 has caused some disruption to the practice and industry of third-party litigation funding, with particular impact on class actions.  In R (on the application of PACCAR Inc & Ors.) v. Competition Appeal Tribunal & Ors. [2023] UKSC 28, the UK Supreme Court held that litigation funding agreements that provide (as has traditionally been common) for the funder’s return to be calculated by reference to the amount of damages awarded constitute DBAs.  The consequences of this include: (i) that such litigation funding agreements are invalid in England and Wales if they do not meet the requirements of the DBA Regulations 2013 (which, anecdotally, many agreements previously put in place do not); and (ii) that such litigation funding agreements are wholly impermissible in opt-out collective proceedings before the CAT, for which DBAs are prohibited (see question 7.3).

PACCAR gave rise to a review of some funding arrangements, the adoption of different approaches to the calculation of funders’ returns, argument in some matters about the permissibility of some such approaches, and some satellite litigation.  Before the UK General Election in early July 2024, a Bill to reverse the effects of PACCAR, the Litigation Funding Agreements (Enforceability) Bill 2024, had been before Parliament.  The Bill did not, however, appear in the new government’s legislative programme, announced on 18 July 2024, and it was subsequently announced that the government would not reintroduce it, if at all, until after a wider review of the litigation funding market in England and Wales had been conducted by the Civil Justice Council (“CJC”).  That review has now been completed, and it remains to be seen how the government will act on the CJC’s recommendations (see further question 9.2).

Importantly, a recent Court of Appeal judgment that dismissed parallel appeals by Apple, Sony, Mastercard and Visa in relation to their respective defence of opt-out competition collective actions brought against them (Sony Interactive Entertainment Europe Ltd v. Alex Neill Class Representative Ltd [2025] EWCA Civ 841 (“Sony v. Neill”)) has upheld the legality of litigation funding agreements that were reformulated to overcome PACCAR.  In particular, the judgment confirmed that a litigation funding agreement that provides for a funder’s fee to be calculated as a multiple of the funder’s outlay in the proceedings – rather than as a percentage of the proceeds that the class representative would recover if the proceedings were successful – is not an unenforceable DBA and is compatible with PACCAR.  The Sony v. Neill ruling, for now at least, provides a way forward for funding collective actions in the CAT.

In addition to new hurdles introduced as a result of the PACCAR decision, there may be existing jurisdiction-specific considerations to observe in relation to any third-party funding arrangement.  For example, at least in England, the funding agreement should not give the funder an unreasonable return or the right to control the proceedings.

8. Other Mechanisms
8.1       Can consumers’ claims be assigned to a consumer association or representative body and brought by that body? If so, please outline the procedure.

It may be possible, in appropriate circumstances, for claims to be assigned to another entity; this could be a special purpose vehicle or, potentially, a consumer or representative body.  There are some reported examples of such assignments; for example, JEB Recoveries v. Binstock [2015] EWHC 1063 (Ch), Casehub v. Wolf Cola [2017] EWHC 1169 (Ch) and, more recently, Commission Recovery (see question 1.6).  However, there may be jurisdiction-specific requirements to navigate.  For example, as the JEB Recoveries and Casehub decisions show, a particular issue in England is that the association or body must generally have a “genuine commercial interest” in taking the assignment in order for it to be valid.  There has also been recent case law in England confirming that a law firm acting for a client in proceedings may not take an assignment of the client’s cause of action prior to judgment: Farrar & Candey Limited v. Miller [2022] EWCA Civ 295.

8.2       Can consumers’ claims be brought by a professional commercial claimant that purchases the rights to individual claims in return for a share of the proceeds of the action? If so, please outline the procedure.

See question 8.1.

8.3       Can criminal proceedings be used as a means of pursuing civil damages claims on behalf of a group or class?

No – civil damages claims are pursued through civil proceedings.

8.4       Are alternative methods of dispute resolution available, e.g., can the matter be referred to an ombudsperson? Is mediation or arbitration available?

Alternative dispute resolution (“ADR”) is an important feature of UK dispute resolution.  In particular, mediation is strongly encouraged by the courts.  Other forms of ADR include expert determination, where a technical point is referred to an expert, by whose decision the parties may agree to be bound.  Arbitration is also popular in UK dispute resolution generally, but requires the agreement of all parties, which is often challenging in a mass litigation situation.

The role that ADR could potentially play in resolving loss suffered from anti-competitive behaviour is a focus area for the UK government’s current public consultation on reviewing the competition law opt-out collective actions regime (see question 9.2).

There may also be regulatory means by which multiple affected individuals might pursue a remedy.  For example, in the competition sphere, they may make complaints to a designated consumer body, which may submit a “super-complaint” to the Competition and Markets Authority (“CMA”) (Enterprise Act 2002, s.11).

8.5       Are statutory compensation schemes available, e.g., for small claims?

Collective redress schemes are sometimes set up by businesses to provide compensation to multiple individuals or entities affected by an issue or incident.  Such schemes may be statutorily supported, regulator-supervised (for example, by the Financial Conduct Authority or CMA) or purely voluntary.  They are an increasingly popular alternative to litigation, particularly where the numbers of affected parties are very large but each party’s individual claim is modest in size.  They can offer businesses considerable advantages in terms of managing reputation, costs and regulatory exposure.

8.6       What remedies are available where such alternative mechanisms are pursued, e.g., injunctive/declaratory relief and/or monetary compensation?

In principle, redress schemes offer flexibility, at the design stage, as to the remedies to be made available to affected parties.  In practice, they generally provide monetary compensation.

9. Other Matters
9.1       Can claims be brought by residents from other jurisdictions? Are there rules to restrict ‘forum shopping’?

Claims can be brought by residents from other jurisdictions if they can establish that the relevant UK courts have jurisdiction, in accordance with applicable conflict-of-laws rules (see question 1.11).

9.2       Are there any changes in the law proposed to promote or limit class/group actions in your jurisdiction?

Given its exit from the European Union, the UK has not been required to implement the EU collective redress Directive (Directive (EU) 2020/1828 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 November 2020 on representative actions for the protection of the collective interests of consumers and repealing Directive 2009/22/EC).

However, there are often discussions about reform of the class/group actions landscape.  For example, when the DMCC Act was passing through the legislative process, there was debate about whether it should expand the CAT collective proceedings regime beyond competition law, to also apply to some other breaches of consumer law.  This amendment did not ultimately make it into the statute as enacted, but it remains to be seen whether similar calls to make wider use of opt-out procedures will continue, and if so, how they will fare.  In Scotland, the Scottish Civil Justice Council are setting up a working group for group proceedings and it is likely that, in due course, the working group will consider whether to introduce Scottish court rules for opt-out procedure (opt-out procedure already being permitted, though not yet implemented, by the underlying legislation).

Given the significance of third-party litigation funding for class/group actions, those interested in this area will also be watching closely for further post-PACCAR developments, such as potential legislation, which may affect the litigation funding landscape in England and Wales.  As noted in question 7.4, the CJC, which advises the government, judiciary and the CPRC on civil matters in England and Wales, has undertaken a review of litigation funding and recommended a series of reforms to litigation funding in its final report published on 2 June 2025.  Its main recommendations concern PACCAR, in respect of which it recommends that the effect of the Supreme Court’s decision be reversed by legislation, which should be both retrospective and prospective in effect.  If these recommendations are implemented, they could potentially encourage further class/collective action litigation by increasing the provision and accessibility of certain forms of litigation funding.  That said, the CJC has also recommended light-touch regulation of the litigation funding market, which is welcomed by many on the defendant side of these actions.

On 6 August 2025, the UK government launched a public consultation to review how well the UK’s competition law opt-out collective actions regime has functioned over the past 10 years.  The UK government seeks to ensure that the regime delivers access to justice to consumers without disproportionately impacting the business sector.  The consultation focuses on four key areas: access and funding; scope and certification of cases; ADR, settlement and damages; and distribution of funds."

Observe this scenario: Between 2010 and 2022, Harry Potter Ltd used a digital tracking system, Albus Dumbledore, which wrongly recorded parcel losses and delivery errors. Relying on this data, Harry Potter Ltd imposed heavy financial penalties on franchise depot owners and terminated several contracts. Many operators suffered serious financial and personal harm.

A 2023 whistleblower revealed that Harry Potter Ltd had long known Albus Dumbledore was faulty. Now 180 former depot owners want to bring a collective claim against Harry Potter Ltd and possibly the software developer, Hermione Granger Technologies. 
In this case, what mechanisms exist for bringing a group or class action, what procedural requirements must be satisfied, and what factors will the court consider when deciding whether to allow the claims to proceed collectively?

### Available Collective Action Mechanisms
In England and Wales, three main procedures could apply for the 180 depot owners:
- **Group Litigation Order (GLO):** A court order for claims with "common or related issues of fact or law."
- **Representative Action (RA):** One claimant represents others with the "same interest."
- **Case Management Powers:** Courts can consolidate or manage claims together without a formal order.

### Procedural Requirements
- **For a GLO:**
  - Claims must share common issues (e.g., reliance on faulty software data).
  - Applicants must show it’s efficient under the "overriding objective" (dealing with cases justly at proportionate cost).
  - A group register is created; claimants must **opt-in** by joining.
- **For an RA:**
  - The representative and group must have the **"same interest"**—a high threshold, meaning identical legal issues without conflicts.
  - No certification needed, but defendants can challenge if the test isn’t met.
  - Operates on an **opt-out** basis, but court approval is required for enforcement against non-parties.

### Factors the Court Will Consider
- **Commonality:** Are there shared facts (e.g., Harry Potter Ltd’s knowledge of software faults) or legal issues (e.g., breach of contract)?
- **Efficiency:** Would collective handling save time and costs compared to individual claims?
- **Number of Claimants:** 180 is likely sufficient for a GLO (courts expect "far more than two").
- **Conflicts of Interest:** Are all claimants similarly affected, or do damages vary individually? If individual assessments are needed, an RA may fail (as in *Lloyd v. Google*).
- **Overriding Objective:** The court will prioritize fairness, proportionality, and resource management.

### Recommendation
A GLO is the most suitable due to the common software issue and large group. An RA is risky unless all claims are nearly identical. The court may also use inherent powers to manage claims collectively if formal procedures aren’t met.
If the 180 people went for a GLO claim what would the procedure be in detail?
